1. Schlichting, D., Hetland, R., Qu, L., and Kobashi, D. (2021). Using tracer variance budgets to quantify numerical mixing offline in a coastal ocean model. Warnemunde Turbulence Days, December 6-9. Talk.

  2. Schlichting*, D., and Hetland, R. (2021). Using total exchange flow to characterize submesoscale processes in the northern Gulf of Mexico. Poster and talk. Download poster PDF. Download talk PDF

  3. Schlichting, D., Lieberthal, B., and Huguenard, K. (2019). An assessment into vegetation farms as a solution to coastal erosion in southern Maine. Northeast Aquaculture Conference, Boston MA. January 9-11. Poster. Download PDF

  4. Schlichting, D.and Hetland, R. (2018). Using salinity variance and total exchange flow to analyze salinity structure in an unsteady estuary. Physics of Estuaries and Coastal Seas Conference, Galveston TX. October 14-18. Poster. Download PDF

  5. Schlichting, D.and Hetland, R. (2018). Mechanisms controlling salinity structure structure in a broad, shallow, unsteady estuary. Sustainable Ecological Aquaculture Network Undergraduate Research Symposium, Walpole ME. August 7. Poster. Download PDF

  6. Schlichting, D.and Hetland, R. (2018). Salinity structure in Copano Bay. Texas A&M University Observing the Ocean REU Student Symposium, College Station, TX. August 2.Talk.

  7. Schlichting, D., Lieberthal, B., and Huguenard, K. (2017). Vegetation farms as a solution to coastal erosion for Saco, Maine. Sustainable Ecological Aquaculture Network Undergraduate Research Symposium, Walpole ME. August 16. Poster. Download PDF

*: This was part of a series of presentations for a graduate class on communicating ocean science to the general public. So this serves as an excellent introduction to my research to a general oceanographic audience.
